title: Photo Deconstruction: Creating Golden Light for Fashion Photography
summary: Lindsay Adler breaks down a fashion editorial shoot in Milan, demonstrating how to emulate natural golden sunset light inside a palace using strobes, gels, and modifiers. The tutorial covers the three-light setup, camera settings, and post-processing steps in Capture One to achieve a warm, painterly look.

steps.action: Set up the first light (Key Light) using an Optical Spot modifier with a Window Gobo and a CTO (Color Temperature Orange) gel to project a warm window pattern across the scene.
steps.tool: Optical Spot, Window Gobo, CTO Gel

steps.action: Add a second light (Fill Light) using a shoot-through umbrella with a thin (1/4) CTO gel. Point it into a corner to bounce light and lift the shadows, mimicking natural ambient light bounce.
Add a third light (Accent Light) using a 5-degree grid and 1/4 CTO gel focused specifically on the model's face to add contrast and draw the viewer's eye.
Configure camera settings to balance the strobe power and depth of field.
steps.code:
Camera: Canon R5
Lens: RF 24-105mm
Settings: 1/200 sec, f/4.0, ISO 400

steps.action: Begin post-processing in Capture One. Use a gradient mask to darken the left side of the frame to direct focus.
Perform local adjustments: warm up the chandelier and paint exposure/saturation back onto the green dress to recover color lost by the warm lighting.
Apply global adjustments including Clarity to add detail and a Vignette to center the composition.
Apply final color grading using the Color Balance tool: add warmth to highlights and magenta to shadows for a sunset/painterly aesthetic.

key_takeaways: To emulate realistic sunlight, use an Optical Spot with a window gobo combined with CTO gels.
Shadows in natural light are rarely pitch black; use bounced fill light to lift shadows and increase realism.
When lighting a whole room, use a grid spot on the subject's face to ensure they remain the focal point.
Colored gels can wash out specific wardrobe colors; use local adjustments in post-processing to restore original hues.
Color grading with split toning (warm highlights, magenta/cool shadows) enhances the mood of golden hour shots.
